Justification: To assess for signs of infection, such as elevated white blood cell count, which could indicate a bacterial infection.
To evaluate the level of inflammation in the body, which can help differentiate between bacterial and viral infections.
To identify any bacterial pathogens in the bloodstream, especially given the high fever and lethargy.
To rule out a urinary tract infection, which can present with fever in young children.
To check for bacterial infections such as streptococcal pharyngitis, especially if throat examination is possible despite fussiness.
To check for signs of otitis media, given the ear tugging and possible discomfort.
To rule out pneumonia, especially if respiratory symptoms develop or persist.
